data.text:
SAMUEL HYLAND

In an original recording of ‚ÄúCover Me,‚Äù the harrowing penultimate track to her breakthrough 1995 album Post, Bj√∂rk‚Äôs voice is accompanied by a seemingly-exaggerated echo, a smattering of crackle-pop noises, and numerous irritating-albeit-intermittent squeaks. Right in line with what firebrand esotericism is exuded by the song itself, these sounds were conjured not by in-studio rumblings nor digitized effects, but the bat-infested recesses of a Bahamian cave‚Äîupon being given the opportunity to record Post across the ocean from her native London, rather than strictly focus on the metaphysics of her music, Bjork‚Äôs intent was just as hellbent on marrying it all to the physics of the terrestrial. The product is one that walks the same tightrope as its mastermind: there are raging dichotomies between being estranged and understandable, down-to-earth and otherworldly, palatable and eclectic. At the end of the day, yet, when resolved on wax, the conflicts all decay into a twisted, whimsical catharsis‚Äîand it is at the heart of this debris that Bj√∂rk finds her home. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to prove the impossible really exists,‚Äù she croons in the cave recording, wielding the playful tone of a witch singing a lullaby. Organs, awkward silences and unabridged nature (larger-than-life water drops, more crackle-pop noises, more bat chirps) overtake the remainder of the track; and even in the absence of Bj√∂rk‚Äôs voice, there is the ever-expanding shadow of the absurd.

Though her career was often fronted by a haze of complex paraphernalia that would suggest otherwise, Bj√∂rk was, beyond just bat caves, preoccupied with the dual extraction of the rudimentary from the intricate, and the intricate from the rudimentary. In an eerily proto-‚ÄúLemonade Mouth‚Äù way, the first iteration of her voice on the airwaves was a cover of Tina Charles‚Äô ‚ÄúI Love to Love‚Äù (1976), performed at a school recital when she was 11 years old‚Äîher teachers loved it so much that they sent it to R√°s 1 (at that point, the only radio station in Iceland), which, in broadcasting it, also just so happened to grant an elementary school student the groundwork of a life spent in the public eye. The following year, still 11 years old, Bj√∂rk released her eponymous deb√∫t LP after being signed by the now-defunct F√°lkinn Records as a direct result of her newfound virality. The album was a collection of covers translated into Icelandic; her mother, a hardcore hippie who had adamantly fought against the development of Iceland‚Äôs K√°rahnj√∫kar Hydropower Plant, took charge over the extravagant artwork: a deifying portrait of the child, backgrounded by a larger-than-life painting of a warrior on a horse. Bj√∂rk was signed across the top of the canvas in a kind of pseudo-Arabic drawl‚Äîfor as much as the songs encased were reimaginings of ones that already exist, the cover alone insinuated the genesis of a new movement. Bursting with the clairvoyant implications of her career writ large, nearly twenty years later, Bj√∂rk would wail the same love-centric gospel in the same cover-song package: this time to millions of enthralled fans worldwide, and as a cover of Betty Hutton‚Äôs 1951 big band ballad ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Oh So Quiet.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe sky caves in,‚Äù she sing-shouts in recitation, ‚Äúthe devil cuts loose, you blow, blow, blow, blow, blow your fuse!‚Äù With every ‚Äúblow‚Äù it sounds as if something is indeed blowing up within her, vocal cords surrendering under duress as the impassioned debris escapes her core.

‚Äú-rather than please the crowd with what it expected, she seduced starstruck revelers with proof that the impossible really existed, channeling her eclectic craft to dangle the key to it in their faces.‚Äù

The essence of Bj√∂rk‚Äôs approach is typified by such artistic iconoclasm, albeit rooted in a fundamental love for two things: (1) love itself, and (2) everything, both physical and metaphysical, within its reach. It is very easy, and probably not too far off, to imagine the singer as a Disney princess frolicking to and fro through life with the sole beacon in the arc being a set of redeeming, thematic virtues. In her case, these values seem to oscillate by the moment‚Äîwhen she took to the red carpet of 2001‚Äôs Academy Awards in a wearable swan, for instance, it was her glimmering childlike inventiveness that was on display. (Critics called it ‚Äúone of the dumbest things I have ever seen,‚Äù said it ‚Äúmade her look like a refugee from the more dog-eared precincts of provincial ballet,‚Äù and concluded that she ‚Äúshould be put into an asylum‚Äù). When she recorded vocals in bat-infested caves somewhere in the Bahamas, moreover, it was her unyielding vision for a crossroads between the natural and the unnatural. No matter what, across genres, mediums and messages, the common motif was a lack of reverence for preexisting structures and the audiences conditioned to consume them; rather than please the crowd with what it expected, she seduced starstruck revelers with proof that the impossible really existed, channeling her eclectic craft to dangle the key to it in their faces. And as much as such nature was iconoclastic in essence, its root always circled back to the very thing that first got her voice on the radio: love.

Bj√∂rk was born in 1965 in Reykjavik, Iceland, a capital city populated with mystical mountainous landscapes, volcanic terrains, and meteorologically extreme summers and winters. At 5 years old, she was enrolled in Barnam√∫s√≠ksk√≥li‚Äîa revered Icelandic music school‚Äîwhere she would study classical piano and flute for nearly a decade. The incidental combination of enchanting natural surroundings and a precocious musical practice granted the singer, from youth, a dual reverence for the sonic and the earthly that went on to characterize her output for years to come. On her way to school in the mornings, it is reported that she would often use her time alone to sing to the world, whether that entailed pressing her face against the moss to hum, bellowing with the wind, or whatever intimate antics lay in between. When a Rolling Stone journalist interviewed her in 1995, she recounted using a Post promotional trip to Sweden to sing alone in a local forest. ‚ÄúThen I heard some noise, and when I looked around, it was five horses following me,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúAnd the funny thing was, because I stopped, they stopped as well, they were just standing there pretending they were invisible, with this comical horse expression.‚Äù No matter how big she was getting‚Äîat the time of the interview, Post had just blown up, and Rolling Stone dubbed her a ‚Äúpunk-turned-diva‚Äù who was finally breaking out‚Äîshe maintained a sort of quasi-fictional, too-good-to-be-true exploratory instinct, forging ambitious and unconventional concoctions in both world and studio.

‚ÄúAnd when the various industries she took part in suggested that she ought to have ‚Äúwishes‚Äù‚Äîwealth, power, designer red carpet wear instead of swan dresses‚Äîshe was consistently too busy frolicking in the garden to remember any of it, let alone indulge.‚Äù

Because Bj√∂rk was nowhere near as interested in being a child star as her native music industry was in turning her into one, she opted to reject the opportunity to record a follow-up to her 1977 deb√∫t, instead undergoing another several years of studying flute and piano at music school. From there she became involved with a number of upstart punk rock bands in the wake of the genre‚Äôs rapid spread through Iceland, bearing monikers that translate to ‚ÄúCork the Bitch‚Äôs Ass‚Äù and putting forth albums with titles that translate to ‚ÄúBite Hard Into Hell.‚Äù As part of a group called Tappi T√≠karrass, she graced the cover of Rokk √≠ Reykjav√≠k, a 1982 documentary centered on Iceland‚Äôs burgeoning alternative music scene. The photo sees her doll-like and half-human, exaggerated round blushes on her cheeks, tilting like an animatronic at Willy Wonka‚Äôs Chocolate Factory whilst clutching the end of a microphone. One year later, she would join a band called Kukl (‚ÄúSorcery‚Äù in Icelandic) upon being invited along with an assemblage of other musicians to play the final show of a dissolving radio program; with Bj√∂rk developing a signature vocal edge seasoned with screeches and shrills, they went on to sign a record deal with the Crass art collective, embarking on an ascent that saw them become the first Icelandic band to play at Denmark‚Äôs Roskilde Festival.

After years spent going from unrealized punk project to unrealized punk project, Bj√∂rk found her first taste of mainstream success as a member of the Sugarcubes, a bizarre alt-rock faction that arose from the rubble of Kukl‚Äôs breakup. They released their first double A-side single ‚ÄúEinn mol‚Äô√° mann‚Äù on her 21st birthday; it was followed by 1987‚Äôs ‚ÄúBirthday,‚Äù which, upon release, was dubbed ‚Äúsingle of the week‚Äù by Melody Maker. Upon signing a U.S distribution deal with Elektra Records, they recorded Life‚Äôs Too Good (1988), selling over one million copies worldwide. The album sounds like a stark manifesto of controlled chaos‚Äîon ‚ÄúColdsweat,‚Äù the voice of Bj√∂rk pierces, audaciously, through guitar assemblages that register sonically as jagged glass shards. ‚ÄúDeus‚Äù sees the singer croon mystically enthralling tunes about a man that ‚Äúdoes not exist‚Äù (punctuated with asides by the monotone voice of keyboardist Einar Melax: ‚ÄúI once met him,‚Äù he says, rather creepily, at one point. ‚ÄúIt really surprised me‚Ä¶ He put me in a bathtub‚Ä¶ Made me squeaky clean‚Ä¶ Really clean‚Äù). ‚ÄúDelicious Demon‚Äù plays host to Bj√∂rk‚Äôs familiar wail serenading the titular figure, corporeal cracks in her voice giving rise to the suggestion that it is somewhere within her, fighting to get out. The Sugarcubes achieved monumental success globally, performing on Saturday Night Live in 1988 and being crowned the ‚Äúbiggest rock band to emerge from Iceland‚Äù in a Rolling Stone biography. ‚ÄúThe Sugarcubes make music that is very much like Iceland itself,‚Äù music critic David Fricke wrote at their height. ‚Äú-A collision of extremes that can be at once forbidding and mysteriously compelling.‚Äù

Somewhere between Bj√∂rk‚Äôs stint in a million and a half upstart punk rock acts and her rise to prominence with the Sugarcubes, she made her film deb√∫t in Nietzchka Keene‚Äôs adaptation of The Juniper Tree, a spin on the original Brothers Grimm fairytale that sees two supernatural siblings vye for safety under the tutelage of an estranged mother. Bj√∂rk plays the character of Margit, a clairvoyant younger sister who often stares into the abyss with intense eyes, seeming to carry the shadow of the supernatural along with her everywhere she goes. In one haunting scene, she approaches her sibling in a vast expanse of empty, grassy hills, abashedly twirling a flower in her hands. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if I have any,‚Äù she says, when asked about her wishes. Her voice comes out in a timid-yet-shrewd silence, the only hint of her shrieking command of the microphone being an eerie echo. ‚ÄúYou always say I do. But I never remember anything.‚Äù As grim as the moment is in context of the film, it is, doubly, yet another inflection of Bj√∂rk‚Äôs strikingly childlike, Disney-princess purity: while the rest of the world worked itself into a consumerist craze as she rose to fame, she opted to remain‚Äîwhether mentally or physically‚Äîenveloped in the nakedness of nature, rejecting a slew of conventional commercial structures in the process. And when the various industries she took part in suggested that she ought to have ‚Äúwishes‚Äù‚Äîwealth, power, designer red carpet wear instead of swan dresses‚Äîshe was consistently too busy frolicking in the garden to remember any of it, let alone indulge.

The late 1980s saw Bj√∂rk go through a series of breakups, the first being a divorce with Sugarcubes bandmate √û√≥r Eldon after the birth of their first child, and the second being a split with the band itself, though she was obligated by contract to record a final album with them before she could effectively make an exit. She moved to London, inaugurating her journey as a solo artist with 1993‚Äôs Debut (the album she recorded at 11 years old isn‚Äôt counted as part of her discography, because it is reputed to be juvenilia work). The record was intended to signify the start of something new; and, at this stage in her career, a definitive fresh start was something much-needed: long another stick of indistinct detritus in the heap of Iceland‚Äôs fading alt-rock renaissance, her solo act would be tasked with lifting her into her own esteem, beyond her convoluted past and into a more coherent future.

Debut somehow manages to channel both elements at once‚Äîit‚Äôs a complex array of eclectic musical approaches, yet it is in this very haze that Bj√∂rk supernaturally, as always, strings together something that feels like home. On ‚ÄúBig Time Sensuality,‚Äù for instance, exactly one track after she croons somber, acoustic-backed romanticism on ‚ÄúLike Someone in Love,‚Äù she unleashes a bass-heavy, futuristically electro-pop dance number straight from the ballroom of an extraterrestrial coming-of-age film, pulsing with the same exact thematic agenda as the jarringly different track that just faded out. On the album‚Äôs cover, a stark contrast from the last deb√∫t project she recorded as an 11 year-old, she is pictured monochrome and stoic, holding her hands up to her mouth with eyes that seem to pierce through the lens. It‚Äôs a mournful image, one that well encapsulates the album‚Äôs pretext: from her departure from both earthly and musical homes, to her divorce from her husband soon after birthing a child, Bj√∂rk did, indeed, have a great deal to mourn. Still, albeit, Debut exudes a dance-in-the-rain quality omnipresent across the singer‚Äôs pneuma‚Äîno matter what, it seems, the Icelandic Cinderella always finds her glass slipper.

Bj√∂rk followed up her (second) solo deb√∫t with 1995‚Äôs Post, in doing so, effectively striking gold with international audiences. Post sees Bj√∂rk as both relatable and endearingly strange as ever, animating scenic arrangements with her shriek, and wielding her masterfully-honed storytelling ability to craft living, breathing, modern-day fairy tales. Most notable of these fables is likely that of ‚ÄúIsobel.‚Äù Over a busy soundscape of Africanized percussion and eerie, oscillating keys, she paints the titular character‚Äî‚ÄúIsobel‚Äù rather than ‚ÄúIsabel‚Äù per her self-isolating ways‚Äîas a woman who completely distances herself from the complexity of the outside world, eventually going on to clash with urbanization before retreating back to her home in the forest. ‚ÄúMy name Isobel,‚Äù Bj√∂rk croons, voice wavering as if involved in the subject‚Äôs warfare. ‚ÄúMarried to myself, My love Isobel, Living by herself.‚Äù The music video for ‚ÄúIsobel‚Äù seems to exist in the same barren universe as her character in The Juniper Tree: in a trippy, disorientingly creepy back-and-forth between the singer performing and a group of people watching the story play out in the reflection of a stream, it purports itself as a fever dream, fading out with the haunting image of Bjork‚Äôs estranged head resting at the bottom of a waterfall.

‚ÄúWith Post, Bj√∂rk set the bionic foundation for one of the most consequential careers in pop history,‚Äù Pitchfork contributing editor Jenn Pelly wrote in a review of the album. (It received a perfect score). ‚ÄúHere is where Bj√∂rk became a perennial gateway drug, not to one sound but to the unknown, which is to say the future.‚Äù In order to be a gateway drug, any substance must be able to fulfill two sets of criteria: the first of which being capability to attract, and the second of which being the capability to hook once the attraction is established. It is in this sense that Bj√∂rk functions as not only an iteration of introductory narcotics, but their quintessential human manifestation: like a living LSD tablet, she invites revelers in with her playful ethos, then hooks them into an inescapable world of colorful catharsis.

Speaking to the aforementioned Rolling Stone journalist, the Brazilian musician Eumir Deodato described Bj√∂rk as having ‚Äúdeveloped a style and a music that I‚Äôve never heard anything like in my life.‚Äù He continued: ‚ÄúWhen I heard her material, I freaked out, and I said, ‚ÄòWhat are you doing? This is crazy, this is so difficult, to propose this kind of style to the people.‚Äô But she does, and she‚Äôs successful at it.‚Äù Listening to Bj√∂rk is, essentially, embarking on the same psychological step-by-step sequence: first comes doubt, then comes enjoyment, then comes addiction. There is a semi-popular video of Johnny Damon stealing second and third bases in the same play during Game 4 of the 2009 World Series; as he takes off for third, managerial staff in the Yankees dugout shout in disapproval, then once they see that he‚Äôs going to make it, they quickly pivot to jubilant encouragement. Oddly, Bj√∂rk‚Äôs artistic oeuvre is strikingly similar to Johnny Damon executing a double steal‚Äîwhen she records her vocals in cave-filled bats, wears swan frocks to red carpet events or takes a break from album promotion to sing to horses in a local forest, the naked eye is seduced into an almost knee-jerk revulsion. But, much like Damon, when it becomes apparent that she‚Äôs somehow still standing‚Äîwhether howling over sonic glass shards, clutching a microphone like a Wonka-manufactured animatronic, or revitalizing age-old ballads of wartime romance‚Äîthe only option left is to cheer her on. The inadvertent cult of personality she enjoyed in the 1990s banked heavily on this quality; it was difficult to understand why or how Bj√∂rk was doing it, but the fact that she was doing it alone made being an audience member more of an honor than a formality. Pretending you got it could have been just as fun as getting it itself.

‚Äú-when you give people a world to live in, even if it isn‚Äôt truly theirs for the physical taking, the ever-so-slight possibility exists that they will also make it a hill to die on.‚Äù

Years removed from her initial breakthrough as a solo act, Bj√∂rk would go on to facilitate a collaboration with the revolutionary New York rap supergroup Wu-Tang Clan, seeking to have group leader RZA contribute beats to her 1997 LP Homogenic. Although that specific endeavor fell through, she was able to reconnect with the faction beyond music on several occasions‚Äîone being at a book signing of hers in New York City. ‚Äú I turned up,‚Äù she told Fact in 2017, ‚Äúand seven of the Wu-Tang Clan turned up to, like, protect me! I was signing books for an hour, and they sent some of their team, standing there with me. That was one of my all-time favourite moments: I had been on my own, so when they turned up I felt very protected. It was magic. In my eyes, they‚Äôre punk. We are definitely [similar] ‚Äì we do things in, like, a ritual way.‚Äù Even outside the context of any strategized, public-facing body of work, Bj√∂rk‚Äôs innate impulse to see the most disparate universes collide made her a walking crossroads, inadvertently carrying with her a lifetime‚Äôs worth of eclectic scenes. In Bj√∂rk‚Äôs world, a thuggish collective of East Coast rap heroes acts as the army of an Icelandic Cinderella with a history in foreign alt-rock‚Äîand not only is it normal, but it‚Äôs just the way things ought to be. The only two options are the same ones available for all puzzling snapshots of her career: take part, or walk away.

‚õìÔ∏è ‚õìÔ∏è ‚õìÔ∏è

Unfortunately, with encompassing cults-of-personality like that manufactured by Iceland‚Äôs Cinderella, as much as there is a sort of inescapable pull, there is simultaneously the desire to somehow prove for oneself that the fantasy exists‚Äîan objective that can go lengths heinously far beyond what original intent lay behind the muse. Over the mid-1990s, Ricardo L√≥pez, a Georgia pest exterminator, began to grow increasingly enthralled with Bj√∂rk and her music. He had rapidly deteriorating self-esteem and a reclusive inclination; as he sought more and more to escape reality and cling to whatever fantasies he could get hold of, Bj√∂rk‚Äôs artistry was functionally a perfect nook, complete with illusory visuals, captivating soundscapes and a foundation in mystical nature. A sufferer of Klinefelter syndrome, he was long awkward with girls, dropping out of high school to pursue an artistic career, albeit never going far due to a crippling fear of being rejected. L√≥pez‚Äôs escape of such grim realities was being obsessively infatuated with celebrities, Bj√∂rk being at the center of his attention: he studied information about her life, paid concerning levels of attention to her career, and directed numerous fan letters to her home address.

Over a number of months, L√≥pez put together a video diary chronicling both his infatuation with Bj√∂rk and, consequently, his mental decline. Upon reading in Entertainment Weekly that she had been in a relationship with the British musician Goldie, he grew furious, and quickly began plotting revenge for what he perceived as a stark betrayal (‚ÄúI wasted eight months and she has a fucking lover,‚Äù he wrote in his physical diary before pivoting to video). To L√≥pez, as put in one of eleven video diary entries, the intent of his recordings was to chronicle ‚Äúmy life, my art and my plan. Comfort is what I seek in speaking to you ‚Ä¶ I am being my own psychologist. You are a camera. I am Ricardo.‚Äù Growing angrier and angrier with Bj√∂rk as the installments went on‚Äîthe extent of his betrayed mindset is perhaps best understood with knowledge that his diary (all 803 pages) contained 168 references to L√≥pez‚Äôs feelings of failure, 34 references to suicide, and 14 references to murder‚Äîhis plan to ‚Äúpunish‚Äù Bj√∂rk escalated from minor infractions to, finally, full-scale murder: the final plot was to mail a bomb to her home and commit suicide on the same day, the intended end being for the two to reunite in heaven.

In his final video diary entry, titled ‚ÄúLast Day ‚Äì Ricardo L√≥pez,‚Äù L√≥pez sat in front of a sign that read ‚ÄúThe best of me. Sept. 12.‚Äù He nervously prepared to make his visit to the post office, then resumed filming upon returning to his apartment, where, visibly naked, he painted his head red and green. Loud Bj√∂rk music played in the background as he examined himself in a mirror. Then, as ‚ÄúI Remember You‚Äù faded out, he shouted ‚ÄúThis is for you‚Äù and shot himself in the mouth with a revolver.

Upon discovering L√≥pez‚Äôs corpse several days after the incident, the Broward County Sheriff‚Äôs Office got hold of the tapes and effectively intercepted his package before it could reach Bj√∂rk‚Äôs residence. In a statement, Bj√∂rk said that she was ‚Äúvery distressed‚Äù about the incident. She sent flowers and a card to L√≥pez‚Äôs family, and hired security to escort her son, Sinder, to and from school. ‚ÄúI make music, but in other terms, you know, people shouldn‚Äôt take me too literally and get involved in my personal life,‚Äù she shakenly told reporters outside her home as the news broke. ‚ÄúI make music for people, you see.‚Äù

As much as (1) the extent of carnage initially devised failed, and (2) Bj√∂rk was in no way at fault, the saga still outlines a harrowing underbelly of creative universes even as colorful and lively as her own: when you give people a world to live in, even if it isn‚Äôt truly theirs for the physical taking, the ever-so-slight possibility exists that they will also make it a hill to die on. Not only does Bj√∂rk‚Äôs music radiate eclectic otherworldliness; it invites listeners to indulge in what infinite candylands are advertised‚Äîthough it seems common knowledge that the way to go about such mysticism is to return to the real world no matter how long it takes, for some, those universes are too enthralling to abandon. The same life-affirming, nature-embracing music becomes a death trap. And once the substance leaves the control of the source, no matter how innocently or monstrously so, it takes on whatever form the consumer allows it to.

The term ‚ÄúStan‚Äù began being used to describe obsessive fans following the release of Eminem‚Äôs 2000 single of the same name, wherein the titular character murders his immediate family and kills himself upon not getting a response to any of his numerous letters to the musician. Up to present day, the term has come to connote a brand of social media-native superfan, educated on the nitty-gritty details of their artist-of-choice‚Äôs career, and quick to jump to the defense‚Äîoften in packs‚Äîat the slightest questioning of what legacy they are sworn to protect against attack. Even so, in spite of its more lighthearted ethos than the sagas of Bj√∂rk and Eminem‚Äôs versions, it remains a dangerous extent of artistic reach that brandishes the same exact harrowing deep ends, if not even deeper, as it did decades ago.

Much of this phenomenon is exacerbated by the internet. As social media allows artists themselves to take on informative roles once championed by news publications and tabloids (today, L√≥pez would likely have found out about Bj√∂rk‚Äôs relationship on Twitter and not Entertainment Weekly), the presence and silence of a celebrity figure alike may each give way to conversations all-but-guaranteed to outlast original intent. Perhaps this is more obviously true for the silence: when big musicians like Kanye West and Frank Ocean go quiet for longer than usual, the narrative ritually eclipses them, with increasingly wild theories serving as footprints of increasingly desperate fanbases. Even for the opposite approach, notorious social media loudmouths like Nicki Minaj and Soulja Boy inadvertently, with their passion, rile up fans to a point where whatever is given them, even if not a direct call to action, is taken and run away with.

‚Äú-she didn‚Äôt need a red carpet to possess people, and before the internet could carry her message for her, it was her output alone that both brought people into her world, and made it a graveyard for those who couldn‚Äôt get out.‚Äù

In Minaj‚Äôs case, for instance, upon catching wind of a critical tweet from writer Wanna Thompson that made a point of her age, she retaliated in a series of scathing direct messages that were soon made public. ‚ÄúWhen ya ugly ass was 24 u were pushing 30?‚Äù one of the DMs read. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm 34. I‚Äôm touching 40? Lol. And what does that have to do with my music? Eat a dick u hating ass hoe.‚Äù Devoted Minaj fans pounced on the matter once it reached their Twitter feeds. ‚ÄúMs. Thompson said she has received thousands of vicious, derogatory missives across Twitter, Instagram, Facebook, email and even her personal cellphone, calling her every variation of stupid and ugly, or worse,‚Äù the New York Times reported in 2018. ‚ÄúSome of the anonymous horde included pictures Ms. Thompson once posted on Instagram of her 4-year-old daughter, while others told her to kill herself. Ms. Thompson also lost her internship at an entertainment blog in the chaotic days that followed, and she is now considering seeing a therapist.‚Äù

The loudest fans on the internet, whether their respective artists are outspoken chatterboxes or silent personages, are fueled by creative ephemera that is gripping enough to be passionately defended‚Äîwhen the silent artist neglects to speak for themself, the captivated audience, mobilized by the music, feels responsible to argue on their behalf; all the same, when the outspoken artist invokes diversity of opinion with their ever-running mouth, the audience, just as captivated and emboldened by the music, feels the need to jump to the defense of what first showed them the light. Bj√∂rk exists in a strange in-between, in that when she‚Äôs talkative, it isn‚Äôt in a self-righteous sense, and when she‚Äôs not talking, it isn‚Äôt in the off-the-grid context of a Kanye West or Frank Ocean. Her too-good-to-be-true eternal childhood transcends the existent structures of social media and its marriage to modern-day artistry, and even without a fully-realized internet to inflame the obsession she channeled, it allowed an extreme case like that of L√≥pez to remain possible.

When, every few years or so, social media holds contentious debates on whether (insert 20th Century artist here)‚Äôs fanbase was bigger than that of (insert 21st Century artist here), videos often circulate of young women fainting at the sight of Michael Jackson, Madonna being greeted by camera flashes and raucous mobs, or Yasiin Bey freestyling at the center of a captivated swarm in New York City. Though similar images are not the first to come to mind when Bj√∂rk is brought up, with an especial consideration of what impact she had on people like L√≥pez, it is beyond necessary to include her in such a pantheon: she didn‚Äôt need a red carpet to possess people, and before the internet could carry her message for her, it was her output alone that both brought people into her world, and made it a graveyard for those who couldn‚Äôt get out.
